comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: More photos of them, all shot at train stations: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/tags/algerian/

comment.author: 37860596@N07
comment._content: My grandpa could be among them. ;)

comment.author: 37860596@N07
comment._content: Yep, my grand father talked about the battle of Verdun as something that changed his life.  Omar, maybe yours was at Verdun as well, you never know; they could have been buddies in some forsaken trench, ducking from German snippers and waiting for that dreaded whistle to charge ahead only to be met with mustard gas and machine guns.

comment.author: 90930004@N02
comment._content: My grandfather, (mon grandpere) was a French officer who was raised in Algeria and led French Algerian troops at Verdun.  They fought there 3 times.

comment.author: 37860596@N07
comment._content:
It's a small world Claudia; had they perished we wouldn't be posting about this picture.  Form what I recall my grandfather telling me about Verdun is that it was a meat grinder, a place of horror and misery that lasted for months.  Both, the French and Germans fought valiantly!
Like General Robert Nivelle said: On Ne Passe Pas!
